results.title: The Ring (Musical score)
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, John Maxwell and British International Pictures
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s first film for British International pictures is a foray into virtuoso camera moves, odd angles, ingenious narrative devices and several expressionistic point-of-view sequences. The end result is a love triangle story given the unique Hitchcock treatment. Up and coming boxer, ‘One Round’ Jack Sander suspects his wife, Nelly’s attentions are drifting to those of another - rival champion, Bob Corby. Whereas Sander is young and self assured, Corby is sophisticated and socially aware - attributes that appeal to the young wife, who leaves her husband for him. The film culminates in a showdown between Round One and Corby, the watchful eyes of Nelly on those she has loved and must choose between. The film’s title has several applications - the marriage band, the boxing ring and the secret bracelet from a tryst. The film has been praised for it’s ability to capture social detail, as well as using expressionist visual devices to convey a character’s state of mind (Geoff Andrew). Note: The film has been digitally mastered and features a new music score composed by Neil Brand. Cast includes Carl Brisson, Lilian Hall Davis, Ian Hunter, Forrester Harvey and Gordon Harker.

results.title: Before the rain = Pred dozhdot
results.creator_credit: Milcho Manchevski, Cedomir Kolar, Judy Counihan, Sam Taylor, AIM, Noe Productions and Vardar Films
results.headline_credit: Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic Of, 1994
results.brief_description: Subtitled ‘A Tale in Three Parts’, Milcho Manchevski’s debut feature film tells three stories dealing with the ancestral ethnic rivalry eating at the heart and soul of the newly formed republic of Macedonia. The first tale follows the fate of young Orthodox monk Kiril (Gregoire Colin) as he attempts to shelter a young Albanian girl from the wrath of the local villagers, thus unleashing the full might of a long-standing ethnic feud onto the monastery. The second tale is set in London where Anne (Katrin Cartlidge) is considering leaving her husband to live with Aleksander (Rade Serbedzija), a world-weary war correspondent, who has just returned just from Bosnia. The last tale documents Aleksander’s road back to the Macedonian village of his youth. Tired of photographing war, Aleksander, finds his home on the brink, with tensions between Macedonian and Albanian villagers at an all time high. (Awards: Winner of the Best Film Prize at the 1994 Venice Film festival). Manchevski was at pains to explain at the time of release that his film was not a documentary on Macedonia or the Balkans, as the tension described in ‘Before the Rain’, could erupt anywhere, anytime. In Macedonian with English subtitles.

results.title: It
results.creator_credit: Clarence Badger, Famous Players-Lasky Corporation, Paramount Pictures and Producciones del Escorpión S.L.
results.brief_description: A light romantic comedy based on Elinor Glyn’s widely read novella, which provided a popular showcase for Clara Bow’s talent. As a salesgirl with Glyn’s magnetic ‘It’ quality, she attracts the eligible store owner. Without straying far from the straight and narrow, Bow’s upwardly-mobile working class flapper manages to combine an unselfconscious sensuality, wit and charm with a hint of wildness. Cast includes Clara Bow, Antonio Moreno, William Austin, Gary Cooper and Elinor Glyn.

results.title: Our daily bread
results.brief_description: ‘Our Daily Bread’ forms part of Vidor’s ‘Back to the Land’ trilogy, which also includes ‘The Stranger Returns’ (1933) and ‘The Wedding Night’ (1935). In his book on filmmaking, Vidor claims that he was developing a style that would integrate a ‘dramatic entertaining storyline’ with the ‘realism and credibility of a Flaherty-type documentary’. This film represents the height of the process. It tells the story of a young couple, Mary and John Sims, who are forced by the Depression to accept ownership of a bankrupt farm. With the help of a local Swedish farmer, they turn the dusty tract of land into a blooming spread and gradually a co-operative community establishes itself, in which support is mutual and money is not needed. The irrigation set piece which provides the film’s climax is justly famous. In 1935, the film was distributed under the title ‘The Miracle of life’ according to AMPAS records. The film opens with an interview with King Vidor recorded by David Shepard in the 1980s. ‘Our Daily Bread’ is followed by 2 short films, anonymously produced by Irving Thalberg at MGM in support of the re-election of the conservative party at the Californian gubernatorial elections. Cast includes Karen Morley, Tom Keene, Barbara Pepper, Addison Richards and John Qualen.

results.title: Journey of hope = Reise der Hoffnung = Umud'a yolculuk
results.creator_credit: Xavier Koller, Alfi Sinniger, Catpics and Condor Features
results.brief_description: The true story of a Turkish couples’s flight, with their young son, from the abject poverty and hardship of their mountain village in Turkey to the land of unimagined riches - Switzerland. Selling everything they have in the world to pay for their illegal passage, and leaving the rest of their children with relatives, the three unworldly travellers begin their journey. After initially being refused entry at the border, they and other refugees like them fall prey to a group of smugglers, who direct them to access Switzerland via an illegal and dangerous mountain pass. Despite murderous weather they are sent on their way, alone, their guides unwilling to brave the perils of the journey. Acted, photographed and edited with impeccable restraint, this is a haunting, dignified and inspiring film. Cast includes: Necmettin Cobanoglu, Nur Surer and Emin Sivas. In German and Turkish with English subtitles. Winner of Academy Award for Best Foreign Film 1990 and Golden Leopard Award, Locarno Film Festival.

results.title: The Man from Maisinicu = El hombre de Maisinicu
results.creator_credit: Manuel Perez, Santiago Llapur and ICAIC
results.brief_description: A film of adventure, armed combat and political intrigue, ‘The Man from Maisinicu’ depicts the life of a man who tries to bring the calming effects of sound farm management into the midst of the fray. The film is set in the Escambray Mountains in early 1964, then the scene of intense conflict between peasant farmers of the region and the counterrevolutionary bands spreading terror amongst the local population while trying to re-establish contact with the CIA. Amidst a backdrop of political intrigue and espionage, Alberto Delgado y Delgado was sent to manage the Maisinicu Co-operative Farm. When his body was found in a clearing in the nearby woods, an investigation was launched and the resulting story of his last 14 months forms the basis of the film, told in flashback. Cast includes Sergio Corrieri, Reinaldo Miravalles, Raul Romanes. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Hitchcock at war: Aventure malgache. Bon voyage
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock, Angus MacPhail, J Orton and Pheonix Films
results.brief_description: Having just completed work on ‘Lifeboat’ in Hollywood, Hitchcock returned to the UK keen to contribute to the war effort. He made these two short films for the Ministry of Information, for use solely as propaganda tools for the French Resistance. ‘Bon Voyage’: might almost fit in as an episode for Hitchcock’s later TV series. A Scottish air gunner who has escaped from a POW camp in Germany and made it safely back to Britain, is being questioned by a Free French intelligence officer. As he explains how he was helped and guided by a Polish fellow-escapee, we watch (in flashback) the perilous last stages of his journey through France, passed from hand to hand by ambivalent strangers through a series of sinister rendez-vous that - he hopes - adds up to an underground Resistance network. ‘Aventure malgache’: Paris’ Moliere Players enact a thrilling tale of the French Resistance. The fact-based story concerns Claurousse, who boldly operated on behalf of the Underground in Nazi-occupied Madagascar. Sent to prison by the Vichy government, Claurousse is rescued by the British, and is thus able to continue tweaking Hitler’s nose. As in his previous ‘Murder’ and his later ‘Stage Fright’, Hitchcock seems delighted with the opportunity to combine the specialized world of the theater with the more treacherous terrain of intrigue. The film was made, as Hitchcock later told Francois Truffaut, to expound the inner conflicts which divided the Free French, and which had become apparent during script conferences. The most interesting aspect of ‘Aventure Malgache’ lies now in its typically Hitchcockian element of masquerade. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Crossing guard
results.creator_credit: Sean Penn, David Shamroy Hamburger and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Melancholy tale about a father who falls into alcoholism after his daughter is killed in a drink-driving accident. Estranged from his wife and fuelled by vengeance, Freddy awaits the release of the killer from jail, giving him three days to live. Stellar performances from Jack Nicholson and Anjelica Houston underpin this searing morality drama that tackles grief, guilt, and redemption. Also stars Robin Wright Penn and Piper Laurie.

Estranged from his wife and fuelled by vengeance, Freddy awaits the release of the killer from jail, giving him three days to live. Stellar performances from Jack Nicholson and Anjelica Houston underpin this searing morality drama that tackles grief, guilt, and redemption. Also stars Robin Wright Penn and Piper Laurie.
description_for_label: Melancholy tale about a father who falls into alcoholism after his daughter is killed in a drink-driving accident. Estranged from his wife and fuelled by vengeance, Freddy awaits the release of the killer from jail, giving him three days to live. Stellar performances from Jack Nicholson and Anjelica Houston underpin this searing morality drama that tackles grief, guilt, and redemption. Also stars Robin Wright Penn and Piper Laurie.

results.title: To die for
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Laura Ziskin, Columbia Pictures and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Gus Van Sant’s vicious black comedy stars Nicole Kidman as Suzanne Stone, a vapid and celebrity obsessed sociopath whose dream to become a famous TV personality turns into a nightmare for the people around her. In her determined quest for stardom Suzanne bullies her way into a job as a weather woman for a local cable station, much to her husband’s (Matt Dillon) growing displeasure, and shrewdly uses it as a way to instigate her own pet projects. Through one such project, a documentary about teenagers, she meets and befriends three of her subjects, Jimmy (Joaquin Phoenix), Lydia (Alison Folland) and Russell (Casey Affleck), three awkward teens with very low self esteem. Jimmy and Lydia take a particular liking to the glamorous and confident Suzanne who seizes on their crush as a way to manipulate them into helping her achieve her own murderous goals. Buck Henry’s (‘The Graduate’) caustic screenplay is serviced well by Gus Van Sant’s direction, which chronicles Suzanne’s ruthless climb to the top of the American dream through a series of first hand accounts from the various characters. Joaquin Phoenix and Alison Folland are impressive as the painfully shy teens, while Kidman’s performance is spot on as the cold and calculating Suzanne. Cast also includes Illeana Douglas and Dan Hedaya. (Awards: Golden Globe Award for Best Actress-Nicole Kidman) See also ‘Drugstore Cowboy’, ‘My own private Idaho’, ‘Good Will Hunting’.

results.title: Beautiful thing
results.creator_credit: Hettie Macdonald, Bill Shapter, Tony Garnett and Channel Four Television
results.brief_description: Teenager Jamie Gangel (Glenn Berry) shares a council flat in South London with his extroverted but warm hearted bar tender mother, Sandra (Linda Henry). Jamie is a quiet and introverted student, victimised by his school mates for being a homosexual, and frustrated by his mother in yet another relationship. On either side of them live Jamie’s abused school mate Ste (Scott Neal), and the delinquent, Mother Cass afficionado, Leah (Tameka Empson). When Ste runs to the Gangel’s after another bout of abuse he finds himself sharing a room with Jamie, and soon begins to question his sexual identity when Jamie reveals that he is queer. In the small confines of the council flats the close knit neighbourhood find out as much about themselves as the new relationship that’s going on separated by the thin fibro walls.
